Unless someone has actually lived here, they probably don't fully understand the constant sight of brown, and when you see a lawn, it’s clear that the homeowner is spending a lot on its maintenance. When I first moved here in the 90s, houses were spread far apart. Now it's mostly the same, but with many new additions. Honestly, this place looks more like a city every day, but I suppose most places are changing in the same way. Most of the time, people are very friendly, but just like any city, there are good parts and bad parts. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly elderly folks, so I guess it's a nicer area. The stores here are mainly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you want upscale shopping, you have to travel; I hardly ever see any Whole Foods or similar stores. The most common jobs in my city, not based on any official demographics, seem to be in construction. I think this is because the city is still not very developed, with lots of open space to build on. That kind of worries me, as I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not eager to go back. Speaking of construction, this is the field my full-time job is in; I'm a drywall and T-bar installer. What I like about my home is the variety of animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not least the stark beauty of the desert itself. The high desert climate and landscape have created challenging ecosystems that need protection and are home to various types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment to coexist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted well to the wildlife. I have three children, and they’re all fascinated by lizards and desert bugs. As I write this, they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As for attractions, we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert. It offers a unique experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Visit nearby Wrightwood to see the snow-covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to complete your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry in Victorville.

When I'm asked to describe my neighborhood, I believe my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are likely homeowners with their own lives, my situation is a bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus where I reside, and the people in my dormitory are my community. I also view the surrounding campus as part of my neighborhood, though to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some similarities with more conventional neighborhood ideas. Just like any traditional neighborhood, the area I live in has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by discussing the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before exploring the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of houses that can be found. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity: the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory buildings. First, in the apartments, there are usually 2-4 people in a room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type has about 2 floors, so on average, there are around 20 people living in each building. Second, there are the actual houses available for anyone affiliated with the school to rent. Typically, these are 2-4 bedroom setups where alumni usually live. However, there are only a few of these types of houses scattered throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorms that house hundreds of students. In these, two people share a room, with some exceptions, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered, we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity, which is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages living in my neighborhood. Most professional staff live in the houses located in the neighborhood, while newer students stay in dormitory-style housing and older students reside in apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be justly described only in words, so it would be best to move on to the stores and parks. Since my school is truly its own self-contained neighborhood, it boasts a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options found in any other neighborhood and the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, everything needed can be found within the boundaries of my neighborhood! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people, kept clean and crime-free by all members of my neighborhood!

There aren't many sidewalks in the area where I live. Everything seems to slope downward, and my house is right at the top of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "workout hill" because many joggers like to run up it during their daily exercise. Since there are no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road has potholes in some places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and power lines strung around the block look worn. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often knock down the power lines, and the constant repairs give them a patched and checkerboard appearance. There are many tall evergreen trees everywhere you look. But people here dislike the trees. They try to cut down as many as possible because the trees block the view of the ocean. That's why many houses are built high up on the hill, with large glass-fronted second stories rising one after the other to capture the view of the bay. It's beautiful at sunset when the water seems to light up from below and the sky turns orange. However, it is mostly cloudy, so you often see most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked in my driveway for a month, and when I went to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. It took me three hours to scrape it all off. There aren't many children around where I live, though there is a school just a few blocks away. Most people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting on people's lawns or running down the street. If you leave a door or window open, you risk them sneaking into your house. I once found one in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are quite large, and gardeners dislike them because they dig up plant roots and burrow into people's lawns. However, my cats love them and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and occasionally a hawk or eagle swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it away. There aren't any stores nearby, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can clearly see the opposite shoreline, even through the mist on most days.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you won't have any trouble finding it! Public transport is very accessible and one of the most popular ways to travel in New York City. Bensonhurst is quite an urban neighborhood, so you'll still feel like you're in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see numerous Asian stores everywhere. Over the last two decades, Bensonhurst has seen an influx of Asian residents. Because of this, you will see at least one Asian-owned store on every block as you walk. Supermarkets and laundromats are the most popular. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents because the quality of food in the supermarkets is excellent, the prices are much cheaper, and it is very convenient. Right nearby, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk of each other. This only adds to the convenience of grocery shopping. I'm not saying Bensonhurst is solely populated by Asian residents. It is quite diverse, with immigrants and their first and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the area are Asian-owned. In addition to these Asian-owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has about ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for children to enjoy in the summer. Since we are in New York City, the parks are, of course, very diverse. You'll see all sorts of people here able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren't many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you'd find are for co-op living or condominium apartments. However, most of the living spaces here are two-family houses. Most people are quite nice, but very noisy. Every day, you would hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house or constantly revving their engines, which will wake you up in the morning. If you plan to visit at night, you should be cautious. This neighborhood is quite safe, but people can be unpredictable. You might run into people who want to cause trouble for no reason, bullies, and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past through physical assault, but that was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package theft. Although it's a common issue, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has fines for not cleaning up after dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you'll see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station or the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the ground everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing to grasp about Portland, Oregon is the meaning of "weird". The unofficial town motto, found on the back of a building that doubles as a pizza place, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts legality in at least half of these roles, is "Keep Portland Weird". For some, this phrase is a nostalgic call to remember the Portland of the 90s and early 2000s, a Portland that was lesser-known and less pricey, nurturing creative and unique subcultures. For others, it is an enticing call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but now as a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the continuous construction of condos to accommodate them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it does mean embracing things that are typically not accepted. Weird doesn't imply a lack of modern amenities or contemporary struggles. Like the rest of the nation, we buy most of our products from China. There are countless ways of being weird, of being not normal, yet Portland also has plenty of normalcy. Portland has yoga, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we simply take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes with items someone is discarding, but they can also be plastic bags or boxes. They often contain something magical, a treasure perfectly suited for someone passing by, surprisingly often. Free boxes usually have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of strolling through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. At least, that's what Portland is to me, but I am just one type of weird among many. Some people I live among would never dream of selecting their clothes from a box on the sidewalk. Those people attend goat yoga (yes, yoga with actual goats) or Timbers games (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all kinds of things. Portland is full of people who pursue their dreams, or dream of pursuing their dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug issue. Drug issues are often rooted in mental health problems, and the constant rain for much of the year, along with the dreary clouds, seems to contribute. Portland also faces a homelessness issue, which no one seems to know how to tackle. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than most parts of the country, but our services are inadequate, just like everywhere else. The non-homeless population fluctuates between compassion and disdain. In this, we are not weird at all.

The mountains are ever-present. In the north, they observe the sun's journey at every dawn and dusk. No matter how much I forget them or how consumed I am by work and life to notice, they remain steadfast, unchallenged, and indifferent to life's troubles. On days when I am most stressed and tense, they insist on being noticed, and when I turn to them, they allow me to rest my anxious soul, lending me strength to continue, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergraduate studies, and the mountains north of the campus were what initially captivated me. The university indeed has its fair share of breathtaking sights in its buildings, ponds, and trees, which hold part of my heart, but the mountains truly reign supreme. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own way. Countless cafés have been home to many hours of caffeine-driven studying. One can walk or take a bus a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks lining the restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and energy as its neighboring urban city. However, this doesn't last for many blocks, as one can once again escape to the serene small town by passing the library. This juxtaposition of atmospheres in such close proximity gives this city a wondrous vibe, as if it beckons to be explored. With this, it's easy to create many cherished memories, each associated with a particular part of town. Whether it's walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or rushing through the busy downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places inevitably are in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a fitting place for reflection as well as for crying sessions at two in the morning during an existential crisis. The latter is something I have more experience with. While watching the turtles, ducks, and insects live their lives, each contributing or playing a role, I couldn't help but ponder my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this enigma called life. So, I walked past the pond, past the park and the little houses that epitomize suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that the sun shone its brilliant rays over the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they always had been. The imposing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, and as if speaking without words, they stirred within me a sense of perseverance.

At first glance, you might overlook it—after all, it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not typically where you'd expect to find places to live. At least, not places most would choose to live in. But if you venture past the old, abandoned Whole Foods and behind the hotels, which are only occupied annually except for a few summer stints for family reunions, you will discover a bustling community. On these streets, within these communities, are a handful of apartment complexes—carefully lined up next to each other like Russian nesting dolls, meticulously taken apart and placed side by side along the road. The first apartments you encounter have been in the news for some rather unsavory incidents, so let's not dwell on those—appearances can be deceiving, after all. However, the apartments next to that complex, and the two beside them, belong to a completely different world that almost no one in the area knows about. Across from these complexes is a satellite campus of a community college—a quiet, sleepy cluster of buildings standing sentinel by the road, where students trickle in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning as they begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan about the traffic when attendance is higher. The road leads into another residential street, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones under unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan that churns the warm, thick summer air back and forth. Across the street at the park, children run back and forth on the grass, doing cartwheels and somersaults over the prickly green blades while bees lazily buzz around the flower patches by the road. Retired folks walk their dogs along the path, frowning at teenagers on skateboards and nodding politely at the teenage girls gathered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There's a sushi place in a strip mall next to the park with inexpensive food that never seems too busy—a swimming supply store right beside it and a nail salon nestled in between. You could prepare your pool for the season while getting a manicure and enjoying hibachi chicken—all at once, the convenience of a strip mall. There's also a frozen yogurt place there, one of those DIY types, and you often see teens in the park holding cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while performing tricks on their skateboards and vaping because they believe it's the coolest thing. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana—a piece of history in the sleepy South where almost nothing changes, not even time.

My neighborhood is quite interesting. While most of the houses are single-family, a few have been divided into two units, yet remain attached, if that makes sense. My home features a small front yard and a driveway on the left side. Like most others, it evokes a time not too long ago when suburban life was the American dream. This dream once embraced the people of this nation, but now it seems to be slipping away. However, my neighborhood and many others still persist, still calling out to us and visitors that the dream is alive, and we are clinging to it as best as we can. The people don't feel as hopeful as they once did, the upkeep of the small yards isn't what it used to be, but there's still a car or two in every driveway, and the youth still play as if their surroundings were their entire world. The public school, which has been here for almost 90 years, still stands, igniting a future in today's young people, while stirring nostalgia among older residents. The churches are few and mostly empty, but the basketball courts are bustling. All the homes look different, yet they feel the same. A large supermarket called Super "A" is owned by a large Yemeni family, who might be the only Arab family in the area. The majority of the residents are African American. The streets are broad, and kids usually play football, pausing only to let cars through. Many in my neighborhood have been here for generations and can share stories of a past where everyone knew each other. There used to be a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, kids lost interest in being the Karate Kid, so now it's a pharmacy, because, as they say, drugs make everything better. There's also a small movie theater that shows old films at a discount, avoided by the youth due to its lack of new releases, but appreciated by the elders, who find it a small cost for a night out, without the kids of course. A single expressway runs through my town, though its exit and entrance are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition to get an exit for our town. The youth supported it, but the elders disagreed. They believed that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, convincing the city council to deny the request. A new high school is being built, and we're trying to choose a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Since I live in a big city, my neighborhood is quite diverse. Residential areas are scattered, seemingly at random, among commercial zones where various businesses operate. Some of these businesses include offices, while others are shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There's no shortage of new places to eat or shop. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by big corporations, small boutiques are also gaining popularity. They are not only located in malls but also line the streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene if not surrounded by so many attractions. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I've noticed that people often visit these parks with their young children. Regarding the people, there is indeed quite a bit of diversity in my neighborhood. In one small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a mix of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Extending a bit further outside my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they sometimes form their own small communities within the city. We have places known as Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, just a few miles can mean a very long drive. Covering only 10 miles can sometimes take two hours due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere. While certain points of interest are inevitably close, the city is huge, and people generally do not prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be hard to find parking spots almost anywhere. Ironically, there has been a lot of construction in recent years, with large apartment buildings being added to the city. It seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the idea of even more people moving in and more vehicles on the roads. However, there are many different types of housing in my city. Not everyone lives or wants to live in a large apartment building. Residential areas consist of houses of different sizes, as well as smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties have single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even within my immediate neighborhood, so there is no lack of diversity regarding housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of various ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with most of my neighbors. It is not really a close-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all close to my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past the cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, aware she would be shocked by the openness of the landscape. She was from a town where the grocery store was only a five-minute walk from her house—she had never seen so much open space before. Overwhelmed by the omnipresent cornfields, I described to her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she understood who I was and where I came from. Driving down the two-lane country road, you reach a quarry filled with water. Just beyond it is the small development where I live. The houses are mainly made of brick and stucco. Each house has at least half an acre of land, which everyone takes pride in maintaining. In spring, perennial flowers abound, along with Midwest trees that change with the seasons. The driveways are filled with high-end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that gleam in the midday sun after a thorough car wash. Continuing along the road to my grey stucco house, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly demeanor. He often spends the day mowing his lawn, his singing audible over the mower's hum. Everyone in the neighborhood finds him amusing, yet he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has aged and lost some of his sharpness over time. In his past, he was a doctor and often blends into the grass with his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you reach my home. In the side yard, geese are plentiful, chased by our terrier. Out back, there's a small stream feeding into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge lies an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This is where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (which mostly meant chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood kid available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be brutally harsh, yet there's nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers become barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister and snowmen. My sister and I often fought as kids, and in winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We built massive igloo-like forts to store our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland, we played make-believe in a time when nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
